Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE - NORTHWEST LOBBY - MORNING
Scenes.Description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 23, 7:30 A.M. A large, decorated Christmas tree stands in the middle of the lobby. Mandy and C.J. discuss the White House holiday celebration, while Toby stands around uninterested, reading a newspaper. Staffers are hurrying around decorating the lobby with plants, flags, lights, etc.

Dialogues.Line: The President will stand next to the tree with flag on the left and the carolers will be off to the side.
Someone tell me why I'm standing here.
How do you know these things?
We'll pad them if we have to. Now, we have Jose Feliciano, we have Sammy Sosa and his wife...
Did you know that recordings of 'Feliz Navidad' outsold recordings of 'White Christmas?'
Pageant of peace, season of hope, coming of the new millennium.
Yeah. Mandy stays behind as C.J., Sam, and Toby start to walk through the HALLWAYS to their offices.
It's not the new millennium, but I'll just let it drop.
It is not the new millennium. The year 2000 is the last year of the millennium. It's not the first one of the next.
But the common sensibility, to quote Steven J. Gould...
Steven J. Gould needs to look at a calendar.
Gould says that this is a largely unreasonable issue.
Yes, it's tough to resolve. Yes, you have to look at a calendar. They walk through the Roosevelt Room where several other staffers are working, when Ginger calls him.
I'm arguing now, I'll call them back.
It's the D.C. police. C.J., Sam and Toby stop on their tracks, and turn to face Ginger.
Huh. [walks away] Sam and C.J. as they walk out of the Roosevelt Room into another HALLWAY.
You got to ask yourself which is more exciting, watching your car roll over from 99,999 to 100,000, or watching it go from 100 to 101?
So technically the millennium is still a year away?
Yeah, but we've made all these plans. They pass by a Secret Service agent, DONNIE.
Donnie, would you tell them I'm on my way over to see the President?
[into mike] Flamingo is on her way. Sam turns the corner, but C.J. whips around when she hears what Donnie called her.
Who? What did you call... what did he call me? Sam reaches from off camera and pulls her away.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: EXT. KOREAN WAR MEMORIAL - DAY
Scenes.Description: Early morning, we pan through the monuments, memorials, benches, and visitors. Toby approaches a police officer standing in front of a bench, where a man, covered with blankets, lies.

Dialogues.Line: I was at the coroner's office. They told me to come here. The officer pulls back the blanket to reveal the face of the man. He's dead.
Do you know this man? Toby, uncomfortable, comes closer and looks at the man.
His last name is Hufnagle, if that rings a bell.
He had a driver's license on him, expired in 1973. Hufnagle, Walter.
He also had your business card.
And he had your business card? TOBY looks bewildered. Then after a moment a look of comprehension comes over his face.
Well, that's my coat. I gave that coat to the Goodwill. There must have been a...
The card was in it... Well, that explains that. Well, thanks for your time.
Yeah. [starts to leave, but turns] Listen, this isn't a crime scene is it?
See, I got the call an hour ago, I went to the coroner's office. I'm just wondering why the body's still here.
An ambulance will come by. It's not a high priority.
And then you're gonna call the V.A. right?
[points] Tattoo on his forearm is Marine Battalion Second of the Seventh. This guy was in Korea.
Huh... Thanks. The officer covers the man with the blanket again. Toby looks slightly bothered by the officer's casual attitude towards the deceased man.
[almost to himself] Merry Christmas. Toby walks away, pausing to look at the deceased veteran once more. His whole demeanor is troubled.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - DAY
Scenes.Description: Donna approaches Josh in the very festively decorated bullpen, as several staffers are busy working around them.

Dialogues.Line: Good morning Donna, and a Merry Christmas to you and your whole Protestant family.
As you can see I have not yet bought your Christmas present.
Yes, and I know you're agonizing over how to best express your appreciation and affection for me at this time of the year.
That and how I scrape together the ten bucks.
I've prepared a list. She gives him a small piece of paper as they continue to walk.
[reads] 'Ski pants, ski boots, ski hat, ski goggles, ski gloves, ski poles.' I'm assuming you already have skis?
Right. They cut the corner into a HALLWAY.
Just pick something off the list, and, you know, feel free to pick two things.
I want to learn how to ski.
I, uh, need to speak to Leo.
He wants to talk about your Christmas present.
So you'll think about the skis?

Yeah. I'll give that a lot of thought. Donna walks off. Josh waits until her back is turned before crumpling up her list and throwing into a wastebasket. Josh then enters MARGARET'S OFFICE. Nobody inside.

Come on back. JOSH goes into LEO'S OFFICE. Leo is sitting in front of brightly wrapped Christmas presents in the table. Margaret is standing next to him with her clipboard. She is having trouble with her pen.
[lacking feeling] We like to spread holiday cheer. Her tone clearly indicates that she and Leo have spread so much holiday cheer, that they have none left for themselves.
[looking at a card] Who the hell is this guy and why do I care if he has a Merry Christmas?
Leave us alone for a minute.
Sure. Margaret grabs her clipboard and heads towards her office, but not before shooting an unhappy look at Leo before closing the door.
I'm tired of waiting for the other shoe to drop.
Lillienfield's got this information. He's gonna hold it till after Christmas when people are watching. I don't want to tell you too much, but I want to make an attempt at a preemptive strike.
Well, you got to tell me more than that.
I want to talk to her.
I'm saying something to keep in our pockets.
I don't want it in my pocket. I don't want it in your pocket, Sam's pocket, and I sure don't want it in the President's pocket.
Lillienfield is coming down the mountain. Leo, this is no joke.
You don't have to tell me it's no joke, Josh. It's my life. All I'm saying is we don't do these things.
Listen, you hear about this kid in Minnesota?
A gay high school senior. He got beaten up, then they stripped him naked, tied him to a tree and threw rocks and bottles at his head. You know how old the assailants were? Thirteen.
He's in critical condition. This is all by way of saying we're gonna have to revisit hate crimes legislation after the break.
Oh, well we ought to gauge reaction before we say anything.
C.J.'s gonna send up a test balloon at her briefing.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE BRIEFING ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is holding a briefing.

Dialogues.Line: The President is scheduled to leave for New Hampshire tomorrow morning at precisely 10 a.m. on the dot, no hold ups, no delays, which means he ought to be leaving around noon. He'll spend Christmas Eve at the Manchester house, then attend Christmas services with his family in the morning.
Is the White House aware that a high school student was attacked?

Yeah, his name is Lowell Lydell, he's seventeen years old, he's in critical condition at Saint Paul Memorial Hospital with a severely fractured skull, massive internal hemorrhaging, and various broken bones and lacerations. We'll keep you updated through local authorities.
Do you think that this will revisit the debate on hate crime legislation?
Yes, I do. Though I suppose the best time to do that was the day before Lowell Lydell got his brains beaten out and not the day after. Who's next?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby is leaning against his desk, which has several books about the Korean War on it. He is looking at a notepad and talking on the phone.

Dialogues.Line: [on the phone] Walter Hufnagle. I don't know... I don't know! I've been holding on for-- I say I've been holding on for the better part of-- Sure. Yeah.
A homeless Korean War Vet died of exposure out on the mall last night. I don't know if his family's been contacted, I don't know... what kind of burial...
Then what does it matter to you?
Don't worry about it. What do you need?
This might seem trivial under the circumstances.
The Santa hats do clash with the Dickensian costumes.
Just keeping you in the loop.
[into phone] Yes, I'm here. [to Mandy] Go away.
Yeah, I know. [leaves] Toby listens on the phone for a moment, then pulls it away from his ear in disgust, then brings it back to listen.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh is walking back to his office when approached by Donna.

Dialogues.Line: I need to talk to you.
Donna, I can assure you I'm giving your Christmas list the consideration it...
Seriously. [They stop] What's going on with Leo? Josh looks at her for a moment, and then closes his door to give them some privacy.
The two of you shouldn't be...
For the moment nothing, we're gonna--
We're gonna wait and see how--
There's not much else we can do.
Yes. She gives Josh a very sympathetic look.
Could you stop looking at me with the face?
Like I just killed your hamster?
[rolls her eyes] I just think if the tables were turned...
If one of us were in trouble, he would be the first person to--
It was my regular face, Josh. I wasn't trying to guilt you.
I know... I have to work.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NORTHWEST LOBBY - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is leading a couple dozen small schoolchildren into the room. The children look in awe at the magnificent Christmas tree in the middle of the room. Reporters are standing around behind velvet ropes to snapping away pictures.

Dialogues.Line: Okay kids, remember the drill, in a big voice you'll say your name, your grade and then you'll ask the President the question that you and your teacher have prepared and written down on your index card. [glances up to an agent, who nods subtlely] [to kids] Okay, how about a big, 'Good morning Mr. President!' when he comes in the room? Here we go. C.J. steps aside as Bartlet comes around the corner and walks in front of the kids.
Oh that sounded pretty weak to me. Let's try it again. [cups his ear]
That's better. Now who are all these people making a ruckus and tracking up my floor? [points to a young boy] You! What's your name?
And when are you gonna get taller, huh? What are you, fifteen, sixteen years old?
Well, all right then, you're fine. All right, lets go. Come on, I'm a busy man. I am, after all, the President of Bulgaria.
No! C.J. laughs at the Bartlet's antics.
Now, wait a second. That's not right. I'm not the President of Bulgaria. I am the President of the Great Kingdom of Luxembourg.
Now hold on, I know I'm the President of something...
Yes! Thank you. I am the President of the United States of America. Now, who has a question?
Me! Me! Me! He points to a cute, little girl with glasses, and kneels down in front of her.
My name is Jessica Hodges, and I'm in the third grade, and this is my question: What's your favorite part about being President?
My favorite part about being President?
I'm doing it right now. [kisses the girl on the forehead] Who's next? All right.
[to kids] Wait. Hang on a second. C.J. whispers something to him.
Okay. [to the kids] Apparently, there's a group of kids in the other room that I might like better.
No! Bartlet and C.J. walk over to the foray where Charlie is standing.
I'm sorry to interrupt, sir, but you asked me to keep you posted.
Lowell Lydell died about 15 minutes ago. The bad news hits him. The kids suddenly become quiet. Bartlet takes a moment to respond.
Okay. Send some flowers. Then I'll call his parents.

Okay. [looks at Charlie once more, then returns to the group of waiting children] All right, now on with the questions. Now wait a minute, when you address me, please bear in mind that you are speaking to His Royal Majesty, The King of all England.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam is standing in the hallway reading some papers, when C.J. rounds the corner and approaches. They talk on the way through the hallway to their offices.

Dialogues.Line: I'm not sure I'd put my foot on the gas so hard with hate crimes legislation.
First of all, I barely grazed the gas. Second of all, why not?
Because we're not sure where we stand on this.
I know where I stand on this.
Congratulations, but the rest of us...
They threw rocks at his head.
I understand, but I'm just saying...
Ah. I'll keep my food off the gas.
What's your secret service code name?
[stops walking] Flamingo is a nice looking bird.
The flamingo is a ridiculous looking bird.
I know I'm not ridiculous looking.
Any way for me to get out of this conversation?
I'm gonna go talk to someone.
Excellent. C.J. leaves. Sam continues winding his way to the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE.
I'm going to be in Bermuda in 27 hours, that's how I'm doing. Where's Toby?
He said he had to run out of the office.
Just me, some sun tan oil and 655 pages of briefing memos. They walk inside SAM'S OFFICE. Josh closes the door.
I need to ask you something. I need to ask you about your friend.
Nothing, listen...  you would describe her as, I'm sorry, what was her name again?
Josh, I assure you, I would have no way of knowing...
Yes. Why are we talking about this?
Sam, I need to know if she would divulge the name or names of any influential Republican members of congress that she might have...
I'm telling you no way, Josh.
There's a thing that's gonna happen.
Lillienfield knows that Leo's a recovering alcoholic.
Everyone knows that Leo is a recovering alcoholic.
Yeah, but they don't know that there were pills. There was Valium. He was in rehab.
He was Secretary of Labor six years ago.
He was high when he was running the Labor Department.
I'm fairly sure that's why he started this in the first place. Lillienfield's going hunting. [beat] Sam, we owe Leo everything. I mean everything.
I'll call her, and we'll go see her together.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Charlie is exiting the Oval Office with some files. Mrs. Landingham enters.

Dialogues.Line: It's important you remind the President throughout the day that he's allergic to eggnog.

Thank you. She sits at her desk and begins to work on the computer. Charlie leans on his desk and watches her. A staffer walks through with big holiday decorations. The entire room is full of red ribbons, wreaths, and such.
This place looks great doesn't it?
I've never seen a Christmas look like this, the trees, and the lights, and everybody singing.
I brought it up because, I don't know, you seem a little down this week.
Yeah, I know Charlie. I tend to get a little down during he holidays.
I never knew you had kids.

Twins. Andrew and Simon. I tried not, you know, I dressed them differently, but they still did everything together. They went off to medical school together, and then they finished their second year at the same time, and of course their lottery number came up at the same time.
Well I would have thought they could get a deferment to finish med school.

They didn't want one. Their father and I begged them, but they wanted to go where people needed doctors. Their father and I begged them, but you can't tell kids anything. So they joined up as medics and four months later hey were pinned down during a fight in DaNang and were killed by enemy fire. That was Christmas Eve 1970. [beat] You know, they were so young, Charlie, they were your age. It's hard when that happens so far away, you know because, with the noises and the shooting, they had to be so scared. It's hard not to think that right then they needed their mother... Anyway, I miss my boys. She looks up for a moment, then back to some papers on her desk.
[softly] Okay. Charlie walks away as Mrs. Landingham continues to work on the papers, trying to put thoughts of her boys out of her head.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. KOREAN WAR MEMORIAL - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby is looking at the Korean War Memorial, and then glances to the park bench where the homeless veteran died. He walks up to a stand with information about the Korean War and it's veterans.

Dialogues.Line: Ah, you looking for anything in particular?
No. No. Just... I'm not a visitor. I was, uh... I'm not the police. I was... [beat] A homeless man died this morning near the monument. [gestures to the park bench]
Yeah, when the weather gets down...
Occurred to me that maybe he slept there a lot, maybe you knew him.
Yeah, he was one of them. Was he a friend of yours?
I'm just trying to contact someone that might, you know, be interested that he died.
They usually hang out around Capital and 'P,' I'd try there.
Thanks. [starts to walk away, but turns back] You a veteran?
Merry Christmas. John Noonan watches thoughtfully as Toby walks away.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and Mandy are arguing while Charlie and a few Secret Service Agents stand by. Bartlet is putting on his coat as if he is getting ready to leave.

Dialogues.Line: Mr. President a couple of guys.
Josh, what are you doing right now?
I'm helping prepare a strategy for the European economic summit in February.
Seriously, take an hour and come with us.
He won't let me send some press along.
I don't understand. How are you going shopping?
Oh I sneak out every now and then.
Yes, couple of agents, an unmarked black suburban. They tell the manager, they clear the store, I'm in, I'm out. It's like nothing ever happened.
Did you know that there's an underground tunnel out of here?
I haven't been able to find it even though I search almost everyday.
To a place called Rare Books, you know what they sell?
The President is doing some last minute Christmas shopping at a rare bookstore and he won't let me send some press along.
Tell her to leave me alone. Sheila!
This is a Christmas thing I'm doing Mandy; we don't have to make hay out of it.
An hour with you in a rare bookstore? Couldn't you just drop me off the top of the Washington monument instead?
It's Christmas, Josh! No reason we can't do both.
Let's go shopping! The group exits the Oval Office.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is talking to a staffer and handing her some papers. Danny approaches and follows C.J. as she starts to walk to her office.

Dialogues.Line: I saw the black suburban in back. President's slipping away, huh?
He suddenly realized he'd forgotten to get you a Christmas gift.
So, I've put together a list.
Of reasons why you should go out with me.

Well I'll tell you what, give me a couple of hours to put together a list of reasons why I shouldn't, then we'll compare them and see where we are. [stops to face him] My secret service code name is Flamingo.
Okay. C.J. watches Danny as he walks away and doesn't hear Sam pass by. She follows as she sees him.
What do you and Josh have going on tonight?
I just meant did you want to come over for dinner.
What did you think I meant?
What did you think I meant?
It's what I thought you meant.
Then why did you say nothing if you are going to Bermuda tonight?
But thank you for the invitation.
Okay. Sam. [stops] What have you and Josh have going on tonight?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. RARE BOOKS STORE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and Leo are skimming through the bookshelves in an aisle. Bartlet suddenly stops and grabs a book and begins to examine it.

Dialogues.Line: Oooh! 'The Fables of Phaedrus,' 1886, first edition, red leather label, gilt lettering, engraved frontice. Phaedrus, you know, who was a slave, but later granted his freedom by Augustus, wrote his animal fables in iambic verse.
Well, nothing says Christmas like animal fables in iambic verse.
That's what I say. Mandy and Josh are in the next aisle.
A few photographers would have killed him?
Ah. Here's one. [grabs a book from the shelf to look at]

A book which if I was stuck with it on a desert island, I still wouldn't read it, 'The Adventures of James Capen Adams, Mountaineer and Grizzly Bear Hunter of California.' I believe I would eat this book before I read it. Bartlet and Leo pass Josh and Mandy and walk to another aisle.
So, you won't change your mind?
So you're gonna sit around in your hotel room by yourself?
I've got plenty to do at the office.
Oh! So you're gonna work on Christmas? Good, that makes me feel better.
Come to Manchester, stay at the house.
Oh, so you could read aloud from 'The Fables of Phaedrus'?
I wasn't planning on doing that, but now that you suggest it.
Suit yourself. They are quiet for a moment. Leo comes closer and lowers his voice. Bartlet is examining a new book he has found.
When you get back from the holiday I'm afraid we'll have to start talking seriously about my situation.
I'm not worried about it Leo.
I know you're not, but that doesn't...
It'll be fine, these things can go away by themselves.
No they can't, sir, and they usually don't. I'm gonna need an exit strategy that'll cause the least embarrassment and turmoil during the Mendoza confirmation.
I don't want to talk about an exit strategy.
I really don't. It's gonna be fine.

All right. You know Zoey is starting Georgetown in two weeks, I was thinking about getting this for her. 'The Nature of Things. A Viviscalic Poem Translated from the Latin of Titus Lucrecius Carus.' Leo looks to Charlie with a disbelieving look.
[deadpan] Well, I think she would like that better than a new stereo, sir.
Yeah. Because it's got brown Moroccan spine labels.
Why don't you head for the car and I'll pay for the books.
All right, thanks. [to the shop keepers] Thank you all, Merry Christmas! Bartlet walks away as Leo walks over to Josh.
You heard what I said before right?
Yeah. Bartlet comes back with two more books in his hands and gives them to Leo.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. UNDERPASS OF WASHINGTON BRIDGE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby approaches a large group of homeless people in a soup line ran by volunteers. Toby is very uncomfortable and unsure of himself. He tries to get their attention.

Dialogues.Line: Excuse me. Ah, excuse me, I was wondering if by any chance you know a man named of Walter Hufnagle?
I wasn't looking for him. I was, uh...
Oh thank you. [starts to walk to the man that was pointed out]
Oh, there's no problem. Down on the end?
Yeah. Listen, he's a little slow. I mean, he's all right and everything. He's just a little slow.

Thanks. Toby walks under the bridge overpass, where dozens of homeless people are huddled around fires trying to keep warm. He approaches an older man, GEORGE HUFNAGLE. Like others, George is sitting by a fire.
Are you, uh, Walter Hufnagle's brother?
I'm afraid I have some very bad news. Walter died last night.
It was a very cold night.
Yeah. 'Cause of the North Easterly wind off the Chesapeake. The homeless man that pointed George out to Toby approaches them.
I'm, I'm... I'm Toby Zeigler. Uh, Walter was wearing my coat and it had my business card...
The North Easterly wind off the Chesapeake.
George, did you know your brother fought in Korea?
Oh, I'm sure he didn't mean nothing.
Sometimes people start things and they...
No, uh, he was in the Marines about forty-five years ago.
It's called the Purple Heart. It's for getting wounded in battle.
I guess he wasn't too good at it, huh?
No, no. Uh, a lot of people were wounded or even killed.
No, no I was-- Anyway, uh, I wasn't sure if anyone had, you know, contacted you.
I slept over there at the shelter last night because of the North Easterly wind off the Chesapeake.
Yeah, it was -- it was pretty cold.
Yeah. And I guess there weren't enough beds for Walter.

Yeah. I'm sorry. Goodnight. [turns to walk away, but he can't leave yet] I'm, I'm sorry. This is absolutely none of my business. Your brother is entitled to a proper funeral with mourners and I think he deserves an honor guard, and you don't know me, but I'm an in... I'm an influential person. [sighs in frustration with himself] I'm a very powerful person. And I would like to arrange it.
[turns to the other homeless man] Are you gonna be here tomorrow?
[to George] So that if I come and pick you up in the morning and I'll bring you back after.

Will you? [walks towards the homeless man] Thank you. Thank you. Let me just, uh... [reaches into his pocket and pulls out a wad of bills and gives them all to the homeless man for him and George] Here... uh... please just take it. [starts to walk away quickly]
Nah man, that's all your money.
No, you don't live around here.
You gonna need it for the bus.
Here. Take it. [hands the money back]
Thanks. [takes the money and quickly leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J. is leaning against her desk reading a list to Danny who is sitting in a chair listening in amusement.

Dialogues.Line: You are a reporter. I'm The Press Secretary. It's an unavoidable conflict of interest. It would hurt my reputation. It would hurt your reputation. Your editors would obviously...
I made a list, got it right here.
You said you made a list.
Well, I made an actual list.
What did you come in here for?
To give you your Christmas present. He stands up and reaches into his coat pocket to produce a small cylinder shaped gift.
You already gave me a goldfish Danny, what more could a girl possible want? He watches as she rips into the wrapping paper to reveal--
I'm gonna ignore your list 'cause I think it's ridiculous. Also 'cause I got a crush on you.
Leo's here? Danny grabs his coat and heads for the door as Leo enters.
Whatever. Listen, dial down the rhetoric on hate crimes would you?
You told me to float a test balloon.
Float it. Don't shove it down anyone's throat. I don't know which way we're gonna come down on this one.
They made him say 'Hail Mary's' as they beat him to death. This was a crime of entertainment.
Beyond the crime itself is a manifestation of racism, or sexism, or anti Semitism or homophobia that are only a tip of the iceberg of the pathology troubling this country.
I'm aware of all that. I'm just not sure it's right to legislate against how someone thinks. A lot of people aren't sure, a lot of 'em work here and I'm telling ya' to dial it down.
My plan is to do nothing.
Want me to come cook you something?
[smiles incredulously] What are you my mother?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. RESIDENTIAL STREET IN WASHINGTON - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam and Josh stand at the front door to a house and ring the doorbell. Laurie answers. She has just gotten out of the shower, wearing a robe and drying her hair with a towel.

Dialogues.Line: Hi. The mood in the room is tense.
Come in. Sam and Josh walk into the front room and Laurie closes the door behind them. Sam and Josh look somewhat nervous and apprehensive.
Well, like I said on the phone, I only have a few minutes.
Right, we'll get right to the point.

Right. Here's what's going on. A guy we work with is in some trouble. We believe a congressman is about to expose something about his past that's gonna be damaging to him. And doing what you do in the universe in which you do it, we though that maybe... Laurie walks around Sam, upset with what he is proposing.
I could give you a name of an influential Republican who likes to have kinky sex so that you could scare Lillienfield into shutting up?
I never said that it was Lillienfield.
This is for real? This isn't a joke of some kind?
[beat] Then get out and we'll pretend that this never happened.
White House. She came to the state dinner with Carl Everett.
Who raised about five million dollars in the mid-west for Bartlet. Did you think that only Republicans pay for sex?
I can't believe you. What, did you get this out of a book?
Oh! What are you, the brains of the outfit?

[voice rising] Yeah, I am. And I got to tell you, I could care less about your indignation right now. A man has left himself open to the kind of attack from which men in my business don't recover. Now if our tactics seem less than civilized it's because so are our attackers and in any event I don't feel like standing here taking a civics lesson from a hooker!
We don't need your cooperation, Laurie, one of your guys wrote you a check and the I.R.S. works for me.
Get the hell out of my house.
Just give me a name. What do you want? Money? I'll give you money!
Oh fine, I'll give you a name, and then I'll hope back into the shower and you can leave the money on the nightstand. How 'bout that?
No, I didn't. [turns away in frustration, then turns back to Laurie] In fact I'm sorry. I apologize. That was very rude.
We wouldn't have asked Laurie, but this person means a lot to us.
You're the good guys. You should act like it.
I have to get dressed now.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 24 Leo is sitting at his desk and is talking to C.J. about hate crimes legislation. Margaret walks in with more Christmas presents and cards for Leo to sign.

Dialogues.Line: Yeah, but we're not just talking about burning a cross on someone's lawn. People are getting killed.
And people get punished for committing that crime. Do you also want to start punishing them for what's in their mind when they commit it?
Yes. Leo looks disdainfully at the card Margaret hands to him.
[reading a tag on the present] Elizabeth.
I'm saying this is an abstract theory. It's not enough to say we're protecting people's civil rights; we have to actually do it. Plus it has the added benefit of being good politics.
We'll get into it after the break?
We'll get into it after the break.
You wanted to see us? Leo stands from his chair and Margaret packs up the gifts to leave.
As quickly as possible. C.J. and Margaret exit the office, while Leo looks at Josh and Sam.
Exactly what I asked you not to do.
You went and saw Sam's friend?
Why did you have us tailed?
On the off chance that you're as stupid as you look. Whose idea was this?
It was mine. Sam was a reluctant accomplice. You had us tailed?
It's not what we do, Josh.
You should apologize to that girl for even asking.
Like I'm not gonna have enough problems without the Keystone Cops.
Is that supposed to mean something to me?
What, the country isn't open Christmas Eve?
It's gonna get bad before it gets better.
I know. [beat] Margaret! Lets get this over with.
Okay. Josh leaves and Margaret comes back with an armload of brightly wrapped Christmas presents. Leo just looks at them in unpleasant surprise.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. PRESS BRIEFING ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is giving a briefing to the White House Press Corps.

Dialogues.Line: There's been no change with the Presidents departure time of 10 a.m. so we're still looking at about noon. This is a half day for us, so I'm gonna make it a half day for you too. There is no more news from The White House. The lid is on. Have a Merry Christmas.
Merry Christmas. C.J. starts to walk back to her office, grabbing Danny on the way.
Hey, Fishboy. C.J. continues to walk, while Danny hurries to follow.
Answer me this, and when you do bear in mind there's a lot riding on it.
[turns quickly and stops] A date with me.
Don't you think imposing additional penalties for hate-motivated crimes is a powerful statement by society against tolerance?
No. A crime is a crime. One murder isn't any better or worse than another.
Boy, was that the wrong answer.
Punishing people for their beliefs is, the beginning of the end. Once more you agree with me.
Take me out tonight and convince me.
I didn't, 'cause there was -- I was distracted by a thing.
I'm not gonna say it again.
Ok, then I'm gonna assume that you asked me out. [walks away]
[quickly follows] I didn't ask you out. You asked me out about forty-nine times and I'm saying yes to one of them.
You understand we're having dinner right?
This is a business dinner, in fact bring your notebook.
[stops] My secret service name is Flamingo.
I have to feed my fish.
Okay. C.J. walks into her office leaving Danny in wonderment at what just happened. Josh is standing by the bullpen.
Okay. Danny walks away as the camera moves to Donna, who is sitting at her desk opening her Christmas gift from Josh. He watches on as she reveals a book.
"Heimlich Beckengruber on The Art and Artistry of Alpine Skiing."
It's got a molted calf cover and original drab boards.
I don't know what to say.
I wrote a note inside. Donna opens the book and begins to read what Josh has written. She is obviously affected by his words.

Donna, don't get emotional. Donna, don't get... let's try and maintain some kind of... He's looking around the bullpen embarrassed. Oblivious to his concerns of propriety, Donna closes the book, stands up, and approaches Josh.

[tearfully] You see!? You spend most of our time being, you know, you. Then you write something like this to me. Thank you. She pulls him into a tight hug. Josh, forgetting impropriety, hugs her back.
Okay. Josh walks away to his office. He stops in his doorway to look back to her. Donna is back at her desk, re-reading his note, smiling.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. MURAL ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: A crowd of people applauds as Bartlet enters the room. A children's choir is arranged at one side of the room.

Dialogues.Line: Hello everybody. Welcome to The White House. [sees a young boy and shakes his hand] Joey. Welcome to the White House. The camera moves to the OUTER OVAL OFFICE as Toby enters.
The President would like to see you.
Did you use his name to arrange a military funeral for a homeless veteran?
You shouldn't have done that Toby.
You absolutely should not have done that.
The President is in the Mural Room.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: The boys' choir starts to sing 'Little Drummer Boy' as Bartlet and the rest of the crowd listens. Mandy is standing next to Bartlet.

Dialogues.Line: [whispering] How would it be if I just mentioned...
Christmas shopping on your own at a bookstore?
[spots Toby by the door, to Mandy] I'll be right back. He and Toby leave the Mural Room and walk to the OUTER OVAL OFFICE. Nancy greets them.
Merry Christmas, Nancy. Bartlet and Toby enter THE OVAL OFFICE.
Apparently I've arranged for an honor guard for somebody.
No, no, just tell me, is there anything else I've arranged for? We're still in NATO, right?
A homeless man died last night, a Korean War Veteran, who was wearing a coat I had gave to the Goodwill. It had my card in it.
An hour and twenty minutes for the ambulance to get there. A Lance Corporal, United States Marine Corps, Second of the Seventh. The guy got better treatment at Panmunjong.
Toby, if we start pulling strings like this, you don't think every homeless veteran would come out of the woodworks?
I'm going to pick up his brother and go there now.
[appears by the doorway] Mr. President, sir? Your absence in the other room is conspicuous.

Okay. Bartlet looks at Toby once more and then pats him on the shoulder. He follows Mandy back to the Mural Room. Toby leaves the Oval Office and is about to leave for the funeral. He passes Mrs. Landingham on the way. She is putting on her coat and hat to go outside.

Toby, I'd like to come along. He gestures for her to join him. The episode ends with a montage of juxtaposing shots of the military funeral for Walter Hufnagle and the activity in THE MURAL ROOM. Throughout, we can hear the boys' choir sing 'Little Drummer Boy.' The hearse arrives at ARLINGTON CEMETERY, SECTION 43. Toby, Mrs. Landingham, and George get out of the car. George is holding a bouquet of flowers. The honor guard carries the casket to the grave. They begin the ritual of folding the flag that covered the casket. THE MURAL ROOM. Sam and C.J. join Mandy and Bartlet. Then, Charlie and Leo join. ARLINGTON CEMETERY. The honor guard starts to shoot their rifles in salute. Toby flinches with the first shot. Mrs. Landingham with the second. THE MURAL ROOM. Donna and Josh join the group. ARLINGTON CEMETERY. The honor guard starts to hand the tightly folded flag to Toby who gestures uncomfortably to George, who is then presented with the flag. George gently places the flowers on the casket. They all stand to leave.
